title: 110_hr5960
content: The Act may be cited as the "Supporting America's Manufacturers Act" and includes a limitation on presidential discretion. Section 421 of the Trade Act of 1974 (19 U.S.C. 2451) is amended to make changes to subsections (a), (e), and (f), including adjustments to duties and relief measures recommended by the International Trade Commission. Section 421 of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to make changes to duties and relief measures recommended by the International Trade Commission, including adjustments to proposed actions and remedies considered by the President or Trade Representative. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to change duties and relief measures recommended by the International Trade Commission. This includes adjustments to proposed actions and remedies considered by the President or Trade Representative. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to change duties and relief measures recommended by the International Trade Commission. This includes adjustments to proposed actions and remedies considered by the President or Trade Representative. The Trade Representative must transmit a report to the President recommending actions under subsection (k) and make the report available to the public, excluding proprietary information. A summary of the report will be published in the Federal Register. Subsection (i) is modified to clarify that certain determinations by the Commission are considered affirmative. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to change duties and relief measures recommended by the International Trade Commission. The Commission will transmit a report to the President and Trade Representative with determinations and recommendations for provisional relief in case of market disruption. Only members who agreed to affirmative determinations can vote on recommended relief measures. Members who dissented can submit their views in the report. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to recommend provisional relief measures in case of market disruption. The Trade Representative will transmit a report to the President with recommendations for actions such as imposing duties, quantitative restrictions, or a combination of both. If determinations are affirmative, the President will proclaim provisional relief within 10 days. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to recommend provisional relief measures in case of market disruption. The President must proclaim any provisional relief recommended by the Commission within 10 days of receiving the report from the Trade Representative. Provisional relief will remain in effect for up to 200 days and will cease upon the effective date of relief proclaimed under subsection (a), a decision by the President not to provide relief, or a negative determination by the Commission. If no agreement is reached with China within the required time, or if the President deems the agreement ineffective, import relief will be provided as per subsection (a). The timing for Presidential action and exceptions are outlined in subsection (k). The President has the authority to proclaim relief recommended by the Commission under subsection (h)(2) if an agreement with China is not reached or deemed ineffective. The President may also choose to provide relief that differs from the Commission's recommendation in extraordinary cases. The President may proclaim relief recommended by the Commission under subsection (h)(2) if an agreement with China is not reached or deemed ineffective. The President's decision under subsection (k) must be submitted to the Senate and House committees and published in the Federal Register within 15 days. The President must submit decisions to Senate and House committees and publish in the Federal Register, including reasons for actions taken. If the President differs from Commission recommendations, the Commission's action will take effect. The President's decision under subsection (f) will be effective upon the enactment of a joint resolution by Congress within 90 days. A joint resolution is a resolution by both Houses of Congress disapproving the President's action under section 421 of the Trade Act of 1974. The provisions of section 152 of the Trade Act of 1974 apply to joint resolutions under this section. Import relief under this section shall take effect not later than 15 days after the President's determination to provide such relief. If the action recommended by the Commission takes effect, the President shall proclaim the action within 15 days after the enactment of the joint resolution. In subsection (o), the 6-month period is changed to a 1-year period. In subsection (p), paragraphs (1) and (3) are amended by adding "or (m)" after "subsection (k)" and changing "subsection (m)" to "subsection (n)".
